awd_titl_txt: IRES Track 1: US-Morocco Collaborative Research for Socially and Environmentally Sustainable Women's Argan Oil Production
awd_abstract_narration:
Population growth and changing climates have made it difficult to ensure equitable access to food, water, and economic security across the globe, particularly for women and vulnerable communities. In southern Morocco, rural women engage in the production of argan oil that is extracted from the nuts of an indigenous tree. As both an edible and cosmetic product in high demand on the world market, argan provides a source of food and income to local communities and benefits the environment by conserving argan trees that prevent erosion and desertification. Through an interdisciplinary field school over three summers, U.S. students will conduct research with Moroccan faculty and students to investigate environmental and socioeconomic aspects of women’s argan production. This project provides professional development opportunities for 18 U.S. students in undergraduate and graduate programs in Environmental Engineering and Systems and Anthropology at UC Merced and USF. USF and UC Merced have partnered with Dar Si Hmad for Development, Education and Culture and Université Ibn Zohr in Agadir, Morocco to provide international research experience for students. The skills and experience students gain through this project will be applicable to other food and livelihood systems in the United States and throughout the world.    

The overall goal of this collaborative USF-UC Merced IRES project is to train an interdisciplinary workforce to research and design socially and environmentally sustainable and equitable systems. Specific objectives of USF-UC Merced IRES are to: (1) Provide interdisciplinary summer research opportunities between environmental engineers and scientists and anthropologists, (2) Educate students in environmental and social life cycle assessment (E-LCA and S-LCA) and thinking to better design systems, (3) Train students in household livelihood systems approaches and ethnographic and qualitative research methods, (4) Exchange research findings with host communities and partner institutions to improve the environmental sustainability and socioeconomic benefits of argan oil production as a model for other food systems, (5) Increase the amount of underrepresented minorities, women, and lower income students that participate in international research and improve the long-term global competency of the U.S. workforce, and (6) Strengthen collaboration between the United States and international institutions in Morocco.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Argan trees, Argania spinosa (L.), have existed for over 80 million years in North Africa. In Morocco, the argan forest area covers approximately 800,000 ha of land in a biosphere designated by UNESCO in 1998. The argan tree holds important symbolic and economic value for indigenous Amazigh communities in southern Morocco. Rural women in these communities inhabit villages near the argan forests and have been harvesting and processing argan oil for decades as part of their traditional foodways. Women collect and crack argan nuts with rocks and extract oil from the argan kernels using stone mills. The oil is used for edible and cosmetic purposes and sold to local, national, and international markets at high prices. Argan oil contributes nutrition and income to local households and provides economic development strategies for women in the region and incentives to conserve the tree. The argan industry employs some of the lowest income earning populations in rural Morocco and thus plays a key role in promoting poverty reduction. 

The overall goal of this project was to train engineers, scientists, and anthropologists to research and design socially and environmentally sustainable and equitable systems to improve argan production in Morocco. Over three years, the field school provided international research experience to 19 undergraduate and graduate students in engineering, environmental systems, and social sciences from University of South Florida and University of California Merced. Participants included 68% women and 53% of underrepresented minorities (Black/African-American and Hispanic), which contributed to increasing the diversity and long-term global competency of the U.S. workforce in science, engineering and technology. 

Students conducted 4-5 weeks of field research each summer (2022-2024) on sustainable argan production in partnership with Foundation Dar Si Hmad in Agadir, Morocco and faculty and students in sociology, engineering, geography, and English at Universite Ibn Zohr in Agadir. The main research areas included: environmental and social life cycle assessment of argan oil production; a household level study of the socioeconomic benefits and challenges of different types of argan production; mapping and geospatial analyses of the argan forest (land suitability, production potential, and potential impacts of climate change and urbanization); and evaluation and design of labor saving technologies and workplace safety considerations for argan oil production. Student participants worked on the three interdisciplinary research thrusts in life cycle assessment, geospatial analysis, and ethnographic teams. Graduate students mentored undergraduates and the social scientists and engineers helped to educate each other in their respective fields, which allowed them to share skills in a real-world professional setting.

The intensive program included training in local languages and cross-cultural skills, lectures by Moroccan professors, visits to a local argan museum and argan machinery shop, meetings with Moroccan representatives and scientists (agronomists and geographers) from national agencies for agricultural research and argan development, and discussions with members of the Argan Rights Holders Association on land tenure issues. Students received hands-on methods training in life cycle assessment, geospatial analysis, household livelihood systems approaches, qualitative research (observation, interviewing, and note-taking), and survey research (survey design, sampling, survey administration, data entry, and analysis). During the data collection phase, they worked in interdisciplinary teams to conduct 68 total household surveys in rural villages located in three main regions of the argan zone (Sidi Ifni, Essaouira, and Agadir), focus group discussions with leaders and members of 16 argan cooperatives, interviews at 22 argan retail shops in five cities, and participant observation in multiple field sites. 

The study has made several innovative contributions to current argan research, including the first environmental life cycle assessment of argan oil (forthcoming in the International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment). Students added new indicators to the social life cycle assessment of argan oil by incorporating human energy, impact of technology, and workplace pain and injuries. The comparative household survey assessed the needs and challenges of women argan producers working in households, cooperatives, and market retail shops in different areas of the Moroccan argan zone. Students presented preliminary findings to Moroccan partners and shared their experiences with the public through a website, blog, and documentary video (sustainableargan.org). Students and faculty have presented research results at seven major academic conferences in the US and Canada and a specialized international conference on the argan tree.  

The broader social impacts of this project include evidence-based recommendations to improve: (1) sustainable development practices for conserving argan trees as part of the environmental and cultural heritage of Morocco; (2) the situation of women producers in the argan industry, including cooperative structures and issues of workplace safety, labor, fair trade, and forms of social and economic empowerment; and (3) techniques in manual and mechanized oil processing; (4) best practices in business and cooperative models for argan production and commercialization. The methods developed and findings of the study are also applicable to similar small-scale industries in Morocco and other developing economies.
